10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-010-9841-4984110.1007/s10870-010-9841-4NoteStructural Characterization of Coordination Polymers of Nickel(II) and Zinc(II) with Polycarboxylate LigandsSarmaRupam1ChowdhuryPradip2BikkinaChaitanya2GummaSasidhar2BaruahJubaraj B.1egrid.417972.e0000000118878311Department of ChemistryIndian Institute of Technology Guwahati781039GuwahatiIndiagrid.417972.e0000000118878311Department of Chemical EngineeringIndian Institute of Technology Guwahati781039GuwahatiIndiajuba@iitg.ernet.in167201010201040108928962862010153201028620101672010© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20102010Abstract

The structural aspects of one-dimensional coordination polymer (1) of nickel(II) with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylate and a three-dimensional interpenetrating coordination polymer (2) of zinc(II) with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligand are studied by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Coordination polymer (1) forms a hydrogen bonded three dimensional network structures. The coordination polymer 1 having a composition [Ni3(TMA)2(H2O)12]n where (TMA = trimesate anion), crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system with C2 space group and has a/Å, 17.3387(4); b/Å, 12.8748(4); c/Å, 6.5302(2); β/°111.620(2); V/Å3, 1355.20(7). The zinc coordination polymer 2 crystal system is orthorhombic, with space group Pbca. It has a/Å, 14.5049(3); b/Å, 17.1616(3); c/Å, 18.1389(4); V/Å3, 4515.27(16). The 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate three dimensional coordination polymer of zinc(II) comprises of novel hydroxo bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building units and has a composition [Zn2(C6H4C2O4)1.5{(CH3)2SO}2(OH)]n. Topological analysis of the three dimensional coordination polymer 2 shows that it has a two fold interpenetrating net topology.

Supramolecular chemistry of coordination polymers are of interest due to their potential applications as storage devices, sensors, and in the areas like catalysis [1–14]. Different molecular topologies observed for different coordination polymers are of current interest for construction of metal organic frames of definite pattern [1–14]. Carboxylate ligands are often employed to build coordination polymers and their directional properties in making selective coordination polymer have received attentions [4, 5]. Multi-dentate coordination ability of polycarboxylate ligands, are often used in rational synthesis of coordination polymers. 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid commonly known as terephthalic acid and 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid which is commonly known as trimesic acid (TMAH3), are source of two such polycarboxylate ligands used in this study. TMAH3 is a tridentate ligand which can form different metal organic motifs [4, 6, 11–16] and the formation of different topologies from such rigid multidentate ligand depends on their synthetic procedures [5]. Although trinuclear nickel complex of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid was synthesized earlier through a double diffusion silica gel method [17], there is scope to prepare alternative structures of nickel complexes derived from TMAH3. Here, we report the synthesis of another form of one-dimensional coordination polymer of nickel(II) with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid than the reported one [17] and also a new three dimensional interpenetrating coordination polymer of zinc(II) terephthalate with hydroxy bridge tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building unit.

Experimental Section

The carboxylic acids used here were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich USA and used without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded on Perkin-Elmer spectrum one spectrometer. Elemental analyses were done on a Perkin-Elmer PE 2400 II CHN analyzer 2400. The room temperature magnetic moment was calculated using magnetic susceptibility balance (model Mark 1 MSB).

Synthesis of the Coordination Polymer [Ni<sub>3</sub>(TMA)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>12</sub>]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub><bold>1</bold>

A solution of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (1 g) was prepared in a mixed solvent of ethanol and DMF (1:1 ratio, 30 mL). To this solution another solution of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (2.5 g in 15 mL of deionized water) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h and transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 120 °C for 20 h in a hot air oven. On cooling the reaction mixture, green rod shaped crystals were obtained. The crystals were filtered and washed several times with de-ionized water. Yield, 98%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3449 (bs), 1608 (s), 1518 (s), 1433 (s), 1373 (s), 724 (s). Magnetic moment μeff: 2.73 B.M at RT. Elemental Analysis: Calcd C, 26.80; H, 3.74; Found C, 26.69; H, 3.58.

Synthesis of the Coordination Polymer [Zn<sub>2</sub>(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)<sub>1.5</sub>{(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>SO}<sub>2</sub>(OH)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub><bold>2</bold>

To a solution of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1 mmol, 0.166 g) in a mixed solvent of methanol and dimethylformamide (1:1 ratio, 20 mL) zinc(II) acetate dihydrate (1 mmol, 0.219 g) was added and stirred for 15 min. Precipitation appeared which was dissolved by adding 5 mL of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) and refluxed for 3 h at 110 °C. The reaction mixture was then allowed to cool and kept for crystallization. Yield, 48%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3390 (bs), 1592 (m), 1551 (m), 1469 (m), 1384 (s), 833 (m), 752 (s). Elemental Analysis: Calcd C, 34.93; H, 3.48; Found C, 34.89; H, 3.53.

Structure Determination

The X-ray crystallographic data were collected at 296 K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using a Bruker Nonius SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromator. The SMART software was used for data collection and also for indexing the reflections and determining the unit cell parameters; the collected data were integrated using SAINT software. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares calculations using SHELXTL software. All the non-H atoms were refined in the anisotropic approximation against F2 of all reflections. The H-atoms, except those attached to O were placed at their calculated positions and refined in the isotropic approximation; those attached to hetero-atoms (O) were located in the difference Fourier maps, and refined with isotropic displacement coefficients.The crystallographic parameters of the compounds studied are listed in Table 1.

Results and Discussion

Solvothermal reaction of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid leads to a one dimensional coordination polymer 1 having composition [Ni3(TMA)2(H2O)12]n where (TMA = trimesate anion). The coordination polymer 1 is characterized by conventional spectroscopic methods and also by determining its crystal structure. It crystallizes in the monoclinic C2 space group. In the structure of the coordination polymer 1 there are two nickel(II) centers viz. Ni1 and Ni2 located in two distinct coordination environments. Both of these nickel centers are hexa-coordinated and each of them are coordinated to four aqua ligands (Fig. 1). The rest two coordination sites are occupied by oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups. The Ni1 is coordinated to two oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups in a monodentate fashion, while the Ni2 is bound to only one carboxylate group in a chelating fashion (Fig. 1). In the IR spectra the absorbance due to the different carboxylate groups can be distinguished and they appear at different positions. The absorptions at 1608 and 1373 cm−1 are assigned to the νa and νs of the monodentate carboxylate. On the other hand the absorptions at 1518 and 1433 cm−1 are assigned to the νa and νs of the bidentate carboxylate. The Ni1 center has an slightly distorted octahedral geometry; presence of chelating carboxylate group makes the other nickel centre (Ni2) less symmetric. Also, there are two different sets of the trimesate ions. In one set two of the carboxylates binds in a monodentate manner to two different Ni1 while the third is bidentate chelating to Ni2. The bidentate chelate formation prevents a two dimensional growth of the polymer leading to termination of chain in one direction. In the other set two carboxylate groups bind to two Ni1 centers through monodentate fashion but the third carboxylate remains in anionic form. Thus in order to maintain the charge neutrality one of the carboxylic acid group of alternate TMA remains uncoordinated and in anionic form (Fig. 1). These anions contribute to self-assembling of the 1-D polymer through hydrogen bonding. In the crystal lattice the chains are arranged in an ordered manner in which the chelating carboxylate group holding the Ni2 center remains exactly on top of the anionic carboxylate. The complementing H-bond effect of the carboxylate anion with the hydrogen atoms of the aqua ligands make self-assembled structures and it appears as highly porous structure as illustrated in Fig. 2.

This in fact makes the complex 1 more interesting as the charge on the uncoordinated carboxylate group is compensated via weak through space interactions viz. O–H···O hydrogen bonding. This weak interaction brings the valence unsaturated Ni2 center on a closer strand to the vicinity of the charged carboxylate ion (Fig. 2). Moreover, the extensive H-bonding via the water molecules as well as the carboxylate ligands present in the complex gives it an H-bonded three dimensional architecture. Some of the H- bonding interactions involved in self assembly formation in 1 is tabulated in Table 2. The complex shows magnetic moment value 2.73 BM at room temperature which corresponds to d8-nickel ions in an octahedral environment. This shows that there is no significant interaction among the Ni(II) ions in the polymeric structure.

This nickel coordination polymer is structurally different from the earlier reported Ni-TMA complex [17]. The carboxylate groups in the earlier reported complex [17] are monodentate and free anionic but bi-dentate mode is absent. The reported complex was a trinuclear complex while our complex reported here is a one-dimensional coordination polymer. A number of complexes of trimesic acid with copper [16, 18], zinc [19] etc. are also reported. Generally trimesic acid undergoes deprotonation corresponding to all the three acidic protons and leads to higher dimensional motifs. However, we have reported a mononuclear structure of Cu-TMA complex with two of the three carboxylate groups remaining intact [16]. The carboxylate group binds to the copper ion in a monodentate fashion. Trimesic acid is also found to yield highly porous [18] copper complex having paddle wheel type of structures leading to a 3-D motif. On the other hand in the case of zinc one dimensional coordination polymer is found to be formed [19] with both monodentate as well as bidentate carboxylate groups.

It is found that the reaction of zinc(II) acetate with terephthalic acid in methanol-dimethylsulfoxide mixed solvent leads to a three dimensional coordination polymer (2) with a composition [Zn2(C6H4C2O4)1.5{(CH3)2SO}2(OH)]n. The coordination polymer 2 is featured by hydroxo bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) terephthalate cores. These cores act as secondary building units. The complex crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca. The asymmetric unit comprises of two symmetrically equivalent but coordinatively different zinc(II) centers Zn1 and Zn2. The structure of the tetranuclear core is shown in Fig. 3. It is interesting to note here that the Zn1 centre is hexa coordinated while Zn2 is tetrahedrally coordinated. Two of the hexa coordination in Zn1 arises from two carboxylate oxygen atoms, two from the coordinated DMSO oxygen and the rest two come from μ3-bridging hydroxo ligands. On the other hand in case of the tetrahedral centre Zn2 three of the coordinations are from carboxylate oxygens while the rest is from the μ3-bridging hydroxo ligand. Each of the Zn1 centers is connected to the Zn2 center through two bridging bidentate carboxylate groups and one μ3-bridging hydroxo ligand. Also the Zn1 center is connected to another Zn1 center through two hydroxo ligands.

Another interesting feature about the structure of the coordination polymer 2 is the different binding modes adopted by the terephthalate ligand. There are two different binding modes of the terephthalate ligands observed in 2, one is μ4η2:η2 bidentate bridging mode connecting four zinc(II) centers and other is μ2η1:η1 monodentate binding mode. The bidentate bridging mode extends the polymer along the b and c crystallographic axes while the monodentate carboxylate units extends the polymer along the a crystallographic axis thereby leading to a three dimensional coordination network of 2. The three dimensional architecture is shown in Fig. 4a. The coordination polymer 2 when viewed along a crystallographic axis it appears as if there are large three dimensional voids. However, topological analysis shows it to be a two fold interpenetrating network. The two nets are held together in the lattice through short range interactions. The two fold interpenetrated nets are shown in Fig. 4b.

Conclusion

We have synthesized and characterized a one-dimensional nickel coordination polymer 1 in which the coordinated aquo groups and the carboxylate oxygen atoms are hydrogen bonded to form a three dimensional hydrogen bonded architecture. Whereas a three dimensional coordination polymer 2 from the extension of hydroxy bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building unit is also characterised. In this polymer two different binding modes of the terephthalate ligands are observed; one is μ4η2:η2 bidentate bridging mode and other is μ2η1:η1 monodentate binding mode. Topological analysis of this coordination polymer shows a two fold interpenetrating network structure.

The structure of the tetranuclear core is shown in Fig. 3. It is interesting to note here that the Zn1 centre is hexa coordinated while Zn2 is tetrahedrally coordinated. Two of the hexa coordination in Zn1 arises from two carboxylate oxygen atoms, two from the coordinated DMSO oxygen and the rest two come from μ3-bridging hydroxo ligands. On the other hand in case of the tetrahedral centre Zn2 three of the coordinations are from carboxylate oxygens while the rest is from the μ3-bridging hydroxo ligand. Each of the Zn1 centers is connected to the Zn2 center through two bridging bidentate carboxylate groups and one μ3-bridging hydroxo ligand. Also the Zn1 center is connected to another Zn1 center through two hydroxo ligands.Another interesting feature about the structure of the coordination polymer 2 is the different binding modes adopted by the terephthalate ligand. There are two different binding modes of the terephthalate ligands observed in 2, one is μ4η2:η2 bidentate bridging mode connecting four zinc(II) centers and other is μ2η1:η1 monodentate binding mode. The bidentate bridging mode extends the polymer along the b and c crystallographic axes while the monodentate carboxylate units extends the polymer along the a crystallographic axis thereby leading to a three dimensional coordination network of 2. The three dimensional architecture is shown in Fig. 4a. The coordination polymer 2 when viewed along a crystallographic axis it appears as if there are large three dimensional voids. However, topological analysis shows it to be a two fold interpenetrating network. The two nets are held together in the lattice through short range interactions. The two fold interpenetrated nets are shown in Fig. 4b.ConclusionWe have synthesized and characterized a one-dimensional nickel coordination polymer 1 in which the coordinated aquo groups and the carboxylate oxygen atoms are hydrogen bonded to form a three dimensional hydrogen bonded architecture. Whereas a three dimensional coordination polymer 2 from the extension of hydroxy bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building unit is also characterised. In this polymer two different binding modes of the terephthalate ligands are observed; one is μ4η2:η2 bidentate bridging mode and other is μ2η1:η1 monodentate binding mode. Topological analysis of this coordination polymer shows a two fold interpenetrating network elements.content: The structural aspects of one-dimensional coordination polymer (1) of nickel(II) with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylate and a three-dimensional interpenetrating coordination polymer (2) of zinc(II) with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligand are studied by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Coordination polymer (1) forms a hydrogen bonded three dimensional network structures. The coordination polymer 1 having a composition [Ni3(TMA)2(H2O)12]n where (TMA = trimesate anion), crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system with C2 space group and has a/Å, 17.3387(4); b/Å, 12.8748(4); c/Å, 6.5302(2); β/°111.620(2); V/Å3, 1355.20(7). The zinc coordination polymer 2 crystal system is orthorhombic, with space group Pbca. It has a/Å, 14.5049(3); b/Å, 17.1616(3); c/Å, 18.1389(4); V/Å3, 4515.27(16). The 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate three dimensional coordination polymer of zinc(II) comprises of novel hydroxo bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building units and has a composition [Zn2(C6H4C2O4)1.5{(CH3)2SO}2(OH)]n. Topological analysis of the three dimensional coordination polymer 2 shows that it has a two fold interpenetrating net topology.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The structural aspects of one-dimensional coordination polymer (1) of nickel(II) with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylate and a three-dimensional interpenetrating coordination polymer (2) of zinc(II) with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligand are studied by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Coordination polymer (1) forms a hydrogen bonded three dimensional network structures. The coordination polymer 1 having a composition [Ni3(TMA)2(H2O)12]n where (TMA = trimesate anion), crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system with C2 space group and has a/Å, 17.3387(4); b/Å, 12.8748(4); c/Å, 6.5302(2); β/°111.620(2); V/Å3, 1355.20(7). The zinc coordination polymer 2 crystal system is orthorhombic, with space group Pbca. It has a/Å, 14.5049(3); b/Å, 17.1616(3); c/Å, 18.1389(4); V/Å3, 4515.27(16). The 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate three dimensional coordination polymer of zinc(II) comprises of novel hydroxo bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building units and has a composition [Zn2(C6H4C2O4)1.5{(CH3)2SO}2(OH)]n. Topological analysis of the three dimensional coordination polymer 2 shows that it has a two fold interpenetrating net topology.

elements.content:
Tetranuclear Zn(II) carboxylate cluster leading to 3D coordination polymer.

Introduction

Supramolecular chemistry of coordination polymers are of interest due to their potential applications as storage devices, sensors, and in the areas like catalysis [1–14]. Different molecular topologies observed for different coordination polymers are of current interest for construction of metal organic frames of definite pattern [1–14]. Carboxylate ligands are often employed to build coordination polymers and their directional properties in making selective coordination polymer have received attentions [4, 5]. Multi-dentate coordination ability of polycarboxylate ligands, are often used in rational synthesis of coordination polymers. 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid commonly known as terephthalic acid and 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid which is commonly known as trimesic acid (TMAH3), are source of two such polycarboxylate ligands used in this study. TMAH3 is a tridentate ligand which can form different metal organic motifs [4, 6, 11–16] and the formation of different topologies from such rigid multidentate ligand depends on their synthetic procedures [5]. Although trinuclear nickel complex of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid was synthesized earlier through a double diffusion silica gel method [17], there is scope to prepare alternative structures of nickel complexes derived from TMAH3. Here, we report the synthesis of another form of one-dimensional coordination polymer of nickel(II) with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid than the reported one [17] and also a new three dimensional interpenetrating coordination polymer of zinc(II) terephthalate with hydroxy bridge tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building unit.

elements.content: The carboxylic acids used here were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich USA and used without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded on Perkin-Elmer spectrum one spectrometer. Elemental analyses were done on a Perkin-Elmer PE 2400 II CHN analyzer 2400. The room temperature magnetic moment was calculated using magnetic susceptibility balance (model Mark 1 MSB).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

The carboxylic acids used here were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich USA and used without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded on Perkin-Elmer spectrum one spectrometer. Elemental analyses were done on a Perkin-Elmer PE 2400 II CHN analyzer 2400. The room temperature magnetic moment was calculated using magnetic susceptibility balance (model Mark 1 MSB).

elements.content: A solution of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (1 g) was prepared in a mixed solvent of ethanol and DMF (1:1 ratio, 30 mL). To this solution another solution of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (2.5 g in 15 mL of deionized water) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h and transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 120 °C for 20 h in a hot air oven. On cooling the reaction mixture, green rod shaped crystals were obtained. The crystals were filtered and washed several times with de-ionized water. Yield, 98%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3449 (bs), 1608 (s), 1518 (s), 1433 (s), 1373 (s), 724 (s). Magnetic moment μeff: 2.73 B.M at RT. Elemental Analysis: Calcd C, 26.80; H, 3.74; Found C, 26.69; H, 3.58.

Synthesis of the Coordination Polymer [Ni3(TMA)2(H2O)12]n1

A solution of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (1 g) was prepared in a mixed solvent of ethanol and DMF (1:1 ratio, 30 mL). To this solution another solution of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (2.5 g in 15 mL of deionized water) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h and transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 120 °C for 20 h in a hot air oven. On cooling the reaction mixture, green rod shaped crystals were obtained. The crystals were filtered and washed several times with de-ionized water. Yield, 98%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3449 (bs), 1608 (s), 1518 (s), 1433 (s), 1373 (s), 724 (s). Magnetic moment μeff: 2.73 B.M at RT. Elemental Analysis: Calcd C, 26.80; H, 3.74; Found C, 26.69; H, 3.58.

elements.content: To a solution of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1 mmol, 0.166 g) in a mixed solvent of methanol and dimethylformamide (1:1 ratio, 20 mL) zinc(II) acetate dihydrate (1 mmol, 0.219 g) was added and stirred for 15 min. Precipitation appeared which was dissolved by adding 5 mL of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) and refluxed for 3 h at 110 °C. The reaction mixture was then allowed to cool and kept for crystallization. Yield, 48%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3390 (bs), 1592 (m), 1551 (m), 1469 (m), 1384 (s), 833 (m), 752 (s). Elemental Analysis: Calcd C, 34.93; H, 3.48; Found C, 34.89; H, 3.53.

elements.content: The X-ray crystallographic data were collected at 296 K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using a Bruker Nonius SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromator. The SMART software was used for data collection and also for indexing the reflections and determining the unit cell parameters; the collected data were integrated using SAINT software. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares calculations using SHELXTL software. All the non-H atoms were refined in the anisotropic approximation against F2 of all reflections. The H-atoms, except those attached to O were placed at their calculated positions and refined in the isotropic approximation; those attached to hetero-atoms (O) were located in the difference Fourier maps, and refined with isotropic displacement coefficients.The crystallographic parameters of the compounds studied are listed in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Determination

The X-ray crystallographic data were collected at 296 K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using a Bruker Nonius SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromator. The SMART software was used for data collection and also for indexing the reflections and determining the unit cell parameters; the collected data were integrated using SAINT software. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares calculations using SHELXTL software. All the non-H atoms were refined in the anisotropic approximation against F2 of all reflections. The H-atoms, except those attached to O were placed at their calculated positions and refined in the isotropic approximation; those attached to hetero-atoms (O) were located in the difference Fourier maps, and refined with isotropic displacement coefficients.The crystallographic parameters of the compounds studied are listed in Table 1.

Solvothermal reaction of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid leads to a one dimensional coordination polymer 1 having composition [Ni3(TMA)2(H2O)12]n where (TMA = trimesate anion). The coordination polymer 1 is characterized by conventional spectroscopic methods and also by determining its crystal structure. It crystallizes in the monoclinic C2 space group. In the structure of the coordination polymer 1 there are two nickel(II) centers viz. Ni1 and Ni2 located in two distinct coordination environments. Both of these nickel centers are hexa-coordinated and each of them are coordinated to four aqua ligands (Fig. 1). The rest two coordination sites are occupied by oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups. The Ni1 is coordinated to two oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups in a monodentate fashion, while the Ni2 is bound to only one carboxylate group in a chelating fashion (Fig. 1). In the IR spectra the absorbance due to the different carboxylate groups can be distinguished and they appear at different positions. The absorptions at 1608 and 1373 cm−1 are assigned to the νa and νs of the monodentate carboxylate. On the other hand the absorptions at 1518 and 1433 cm−1 are assigned to the νa and νs of the bidentate carboxylate. The Ni1 center has an slightly distorted octahedral geometry; presence of chelating carboxylate group makes the other nickel centre (Ni2) less symmetric. Also, there are two different sets of the trimesate ions. In one set two of the carboxylates binds in a monodentate manner to two different Ni1 while the third is bidentate chelating to Ni2. The bidentate chelate formation prevents a two dimensional growth of the polymer leading to termination of chain in one direction. In the other set two carboxylate groups bind to two Ni1 centers through monodentate fashion but the third carboxylate remains in anionic form. Thus in order to maintain the charge neutrality one of the carboxylic acid group of alternate TMA remains uncoordinated and in anionic form (Fig. 1). These anions contribute to self-assembling of the 1-D polymer through hydrogen bonding. In the crystal lattice the chains are arranged in an ordered manner in which the chelating carboxylate group holding the Ni2 center remains exactly on top of the anionic carboxylate. The complementing H-bond effect of the carboxylate anion with the hydrogen atoms of the aqua ligands make self-assembled structures and it appears as highly porous structure as illustrated in Fig. 2.

Results and Discussion

Solvothermal reaction of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid leads to a one dimensional coordination polymer 1 having composition [Ni3(TMA)2(H2O)12]n where (TMA = trimesate anion). The coordination polymer 1 is characterized by conventional spectroscopic methods and also by determining its crystal structure. It crystallizes in the monoclinic C2 space group. In the structure of the coordination polymer 1 there are two nickel(II) centers viz. Ni1 and Ni2 located in two distinct coordination environments. Both of these nickel centers are hexa-coordinated and each of them are coordinated to four aqua ligands (Fig. 1). The rest two coordination sites are occupied by oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups. The Ni1 is coordinated to two oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups in a monodentate fashion, while the Ni2 is bound to only one carboxylate group in a chelating fashion (Fig. 1). In the IR spectra the absorbance due to the different carboxylate groups can be distinguished and they appear at different positions. The absorptions at 1608 and 1373 cm-1 are assigned to the νa and νs of the monodentate carboxylate. On the other hand the absorptions at 1518 and 1433 cm-1 are assigned to the νa and νs of the bidentate carboxylate. The Ni1 center has an slightly distorted octahedral geometry; presence of chelating carboxylate group makes the other nickel centre (Ni2) less symmetric. Also, there are two different sets of the trimesate ions. In one set two of the carboxylates binds in a monodentate manner to two different Ni1 while the third is bidentate chelating to Ni2. The bidentate chelate formation prevents a two dimensional growth of the polymer leading to termination of chain in one direction. In the other set two carboxylate groups bind to two Ni1 centers through monodentate fashion but the third carboxylate remains in anionic form. Thus in order to maintain the charge neutrality one of the carboxylic acid group of alternate TMA remains uncoordinated and in anionic form (Fig. 1). These anions contribute to self-assembling of the 1-D polymer through hydrogen bonding. In the crystal lattice the chains are arranged in an ordered manner in which the chelating carboxylate group holding the Ni2 center remains exactly on top of the anionic carboxylate. The complementing H-bond effect of the carboxylate anion with the hydrogen atoms of the aqua ligands make self-assembled structures and it appears as highly porous structure as illustrated in Fig. 2.

elements.content: This in fact makes the complex 1 more interesting as the charge on the uncoordinated carboxylate group is compensated via weak through space interactions viz. O–H···O hydrogen bonding. This weak interaction brings the valence unsaturated Ni2 center on a closer strand to the vicinity of the charged carboxylate ion (Fig. 2). Moreover, the extensive H-bonding via the water molecules as well as the carboxylate ligands present in the complex gives it an H-bonded three dimensional architecture. Some of the H- bonding interactions involved in self assembly formation in 1 is tabulated in Table 2. The complex shows magnetic moment value 2.73 BM at room temperature which corresponds to d8-nickel ions in an octahedral environment. This shows that there is no significant interaction among the Ni(II) ions in the polymeric structure.

This nickel coordination polymer is structurally different from the earlier reported Ni-TMA complex [17]. The carboxylate groups in the earlier reported complex [17] are monodentate and free anionic but bi-dentate mode is absent. The reported complex was a trinuclear complex while our complex reported here is a one-dimensional coordination polymer. A number of complexes of trimesic acid with copper [16, 18], zinc [19] etc. are also reported. Generally trimesic acid undergoes deprotonation corresponding to all the three acidic protons and leads to higher dimensional motifs. However, we have reported a mononuclear structure of Cu-TMA complex with two of the three carboxylate groups remaining intact [16]. The carboxylate group binds to the copper ion in a monodentate fashion. Trimesic acid is also found to yield highly porous [18] copper complex having paddle wheel type of structures leading to a 3-D motif. On the other hand in the case of zinc one dimensional coordination polymer is found to be formed [19] with both monodentate as well as bidentate carboxylate groups.

On the other hand in the case of zinc one dimensional coordination polymer is found to be formed [19] with both monodentate as well as bidentate carboxylate groups.

elements.content: It is found that the reaction of zinc(II) acetate with terephthalic acid in methanol-dimethylsulfoxide mixed solvent leads to a three dimensional coordination polymer (2) with a composition [Zn2(C6H4C2O4)1.5{(CH3)2SO}2(OH)]n. The coordination polymer 2 is featured by hydroxo bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) terephthalate cores. These cores act as secondary building units. The complex crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca. The asymmetric unit comprises of two symmetrically equivalent but coordinatively different zinc(II) centers Zn1 and Zn2. The structure of the tetranuclear core is shown in Fig. 3. It is interesting to note here that the Zn1 centre is hexa coordinated while Zn2 is tetrahedrally coordinated. Two of the hexa coordination in Zn1 arises from two carboxylate oxygen atoms, two from the coordinated DMSO oxygen and the rest two come from μ3-bridging hydroxo ligands. On the other hand in case of the tetrahedral centre Zn2 three of the coordinations are from carboxylate oxygens while the rest is from the μ3-bridging hydroxo ligand. Each of the Zn1 centers is connected to the Zn2 center through two bridging bidentate carboxylate groups and one μ3-bridging hydroxo ligand. Also the Zn1 center is connected to another Zn1 center through two hydroxo ligands.

elements.content: Another interesting feature about the structure of the coordination polymer 2 is the different binding modes adopted by the terephthalate ligand. There are two different binding modes of the terephthalate ligands observed in 2, one is μ4η2:η2 bidentate bridging mode connecting four zinc(II) centers and other is μ2η1:η1 monodentate binding mode. The bidentate bridging mode extends the polymer along the b and c crystallographic axes while the monodentate carboxylate units extends the polymer along the a crystallographic axis thereby leading to a three dimensional coordination network of 2. The three dimensional architecture is shown in Fig. 4a. The coordination polymer 2 when viewed along a crystallographic axis it appears as if there are large three dimensional voids. However, topological analysis shows it to be a two fold interpenetrating network. The two nets are held together in the lattice through short range interactions. The two fold interpenetrated nets are shown in Fig. 4b.

elements.content: We have synthesized and characterized a one-dimensional nickel coordination polymer 1 in which the coordinated aquo groups and the carboxylate oxygen atoms are hydrogen bonded to form a three dimensional hydrogen bonded architecture. Whereas a three dimensional coordination polymer 2 from the extension of hydroxy bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building unit is also characterised. In this polymer two different binding modes of the terephthalate ligands are observed; one is μ4η2:η2 bidentate bridging mode and other is μ2η1:η1 monodentate binding mode. Topological analysis of this coordination polymer shows a two fold interpenetrating network structure.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have synthesized and characterized a one-dimensional nickel coordination polymer 1 in which the coordinated aquo groups and the carboxylate oxygen atoms are hydrogen bonded to form a three dimensional hydrogen bonded architecture. Whereas a three dimensional coordination polymer 2 from the extension of hydroxy bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building unit is also characterised. In this polymer two different binding modes of the terephthalate ligands are observed; one is μ4η2:η2 bidentate bridging mode and other is μ2η1:η1 monodentate binding mode. Topological analysis of this coordination polymer shows a two fold interpenetrating network structure.

A solution of 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (1 g) was prepared in a mixed solvent of ethanol and DMF (1:1 ratio, 30 mL). To this solution another solution of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (2.5 g in 15 mL of deionized water) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h and transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 120 °C for 20 h in a hot air oven. On cooling the reaction mixture, green rod shaped crystals were obtained. The crystals were filtered and washed several times with de-ionized water. Yield, 98%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3449 (bs), 1608 (s), 1518 (s), 1433 (s), 1373 (s), 724 (s). Magnetic moment μeff: 2.73 B.M at RT. Elemental Analysis: Calcd C, 26.80; H, 3.74; Found C, 26.69; H, 3.58.

Synthesis of the Coordination Polymer [Zn<sub>2</sub>(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)<sub>1.5</sub>{(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>SO}<sub>2</sub>(OH)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub><bold>2</bold>

To a solution of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1 mmol, 0.166 g) in a mixed solvent of methanol and dimethylformamide (1:1 ratio, 20 mL) zinc(II) acetate dihydrate (1 mmol, 0.219 g) was added and stirred for 15 min. Precipitation appeared which was dissolved by adding 5 mL of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) and refluxed for 3 h at 110 °C. The reaction mixture was then allowed to cool and kept for crystallization. Yield, 48%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3390 (bs), 1592 (m), 1551 (m), 1469 (m), 1384 (s), 833 (m), 752 (s). Elemental Analysis: Calcd C, 34.93; H, 3.48; Found C, 34.89; H, 3.53.

The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h and transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 120 °C for 20 h in a hot air oven. Synthesis of the Coordination Polymer [Zn2(C6H4C2O4)1.5{(CH3)2SO}2(OH)]n2

To a solution of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1 mmol, 0.166 g) in a mixed solvent of methanol and dimethylformamide (1:1 ratio, 20 mL) zinc(II) acetate dihydrate (1 mmol, 0.219 g) was added and stirred for 15 min. cln_elements.content:
The structural aspects of one-dimensional coordination polymer (1) of nickel(II) with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylate and a three-dimensional interpenetrating coordination polymer (2) of zinc(II) with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligand are studied by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Coordination polymer (1) forms a hydrogen bonded three dimensional network structures. The coordination polymer 1 having a composition [Ni3(TMA)2(H2O)12]n where (TMA = trimesate anion), crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system with C2 space group and has a/Å, 17.3387(4); b/Å, 12.8748(4); c/Å, 6.5302(2); β/°111.620(2); V/Å3, 1355.20(7). The zinc coordination polymer 2 crystal system is orthorhombic, with space group Pbca. It has a/Å, 14.5049(3); b/Å, 17.1616(3); c/Å, 18.1389(4); V/Å3, 4515.27(16). The 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate three dimensional coordination polymer of zinc(II) comprises of novel hydroxo bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building units and has a composition [Zn2(C6H4C2O4)1.5{(CH3)2SO}2(OH)]n. Topological analysis of the three dimensional coordination polymer 2 shows that it has a two fold interpenetrating net topology.

This in fact makes the complex 1 more interesting as the charge on the uncoordinated carboxylate group is compensated via weak through space interactions viz. O–H···O hydrogen bonding. This weak interaction brings the valence unsaturated Ni2 center on a closer strand to the vicinity of the charged carboxylate ion (Fig. 2). Moreover, the extensive H-bonding via the water molecules as well as the carboxylate ligands present in the complex gives it an H-bonded three dimensional architecture. Some of the H- bonding interactions involved in self assembly formation in 1 is tabulated in Table 2. The complex shows magnetic moment value 2.73 BM at room temperature which corresponds to d8-nickel ions in an octahedral environment. This shows that there is no significant interaction among the Ni(II) ions in the polymeric structure.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The structural aspects of one-dimensional coordination polymer (1) of nickel(II) with 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylate and a three-dimensional interpenetrating coordination polymer (2) of zinc(II) with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligand are studied by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Coordination polymer (1) forms a hydrogen bonded three dimensional network structures. The coordination polymer 1 having a composition [Ni3(TMA)2(H2O)12]n where (TMA = trimesate anion), crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system with C2 space group and has a/Å, 17.3387(4); b/Å, 12.8748(4); c/Å, 6.5302(2); β/°111.620(2); V/Å3, 1355.20(7). The zinc coordination polymer 2 crystal system is orthorhombic, with space group Pbca. It has a/Å, 14.5049(3); b/Å, 17.1616(3); c/Å, 18.1389(4); V/Å3, 4515.27(16). The 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate three dimensional coordination polymer of zinc(II) comprises of novel hydroxo bridged tetranuclear zinc(II) secondary building units and has a composition [Zn2(C6H4C2O4)1.5{(CH3)2SO}2(OH)]n. Topological analysis of the three dimensional coordination polymer 2 shows that it has a two fold interpenetrating net topology.

This in fact makes the complex 1 more interesting as the charge on the uncoordinated carboxylate group is compensated via weak through space interactions viz. O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding. This weak interaction brings the valence unsaturated Ni2 center on a closer strand to the vicinity of the charged carboxylate ion (Fig. 2). Moreover, the extensive H-bonding via the water molecules as well as the carboxylate ligands present in the complex gives it an H-bonded three dimensional architecture. Some of the H- bonding interactions involved in self assembly formation in 1 is tabulated in Table 2. The complex shows magnetic moment value 2.73 BM at room temperature which corresponds to d8-nickel ions in an octahedral environment. This shows that there is no significant interaction among the Ni(II) ions in the polymeric structure.
